moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 exd4 4. Nxd4 Bc5 5. Be3 Qf6 6. c3 Qg6 7. Qf3 Ne5 8. Qe2
comment:
This seems to be a new move. It's interesting that this year Ivan
Sokolov already suffered from a novelty involving Qe2 - in his game against
Alexander Morozevich in Sarajevo, which went 1 e4 e5 2 f4 exf4 3 Nf3 Ne7 4 d4
d5 5 Qe2!.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 exd4 4. Nxd4 Bc5 5. Be3 Qf6 6. c3 Qg6 7. Qf3 Ne5 8. Qe2 Nh6 9. f4 Neg4 10. f5 Qf6 11. Bg1 O-O 12. Nd2 Ne5 13. O-O-O Qa6
comment:
It is easy to criticise
Black's decision to settle for a unpleasant ending, but White's pawn storm on
the kingside could be even more unpleasant!

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 exd4 4. Nxd4 Bc5 5. Be3 Qf6 6. c3 Qg6 7. Qf3 Ne5 8. Qe2 Nh6 9. f4 Neg4 10. f5 Qf6 11. Bg1 O-O 12. Nd2 Ne5 13. O-O-O Qa6 14. Qxa6 bxa6 15. N4f3
comment: Pieces like the black knight on e5 must be eliminated!

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 exd4 4. Nxd4 Bc5 5. Be3 Qf6 6. c3 Qg6 7. Qf3 Ne5 8. Qe2 Nh6 9. f4 Neg4 10. f5 Qf6 11. Bg1 O-O 12. Nd2 Ne5 13. O-O-O Qa6 14. Qxa6 bxa6 15. N4f3 Bxg1 16. Rxg1 Nhg4 17. h3 Nxf3 18. gxf3 Ne3 19. Re1 Nxf1 20. Rexf1 f6 21. h4 Bb7 22. Nb3
comment:
Numerous exchanges did not improve Black's position - his bishop is pretty
limited, while White's knight has lots of attractive squares. Now it is going
to c5.
